elements.content: Two new chiral copper­(II) coordination polymers comprising octacopper­(II) subcomponents were synthesized through investigation of the interplay among tartrate ligands, guanidinium cations, and metals. Our analysis confirms that these compounds are enantiomers exhibiting 3D hierarchical supramolecular structures that are constituted by 2D sublayers and sustained by noncovalent bonding interactions.
elements.clean_text: Two new chiral copper(II) coordination polymers comprising octacopper(II) subcomponents were synthesized through investigation of the interplay among tartrate ligands, guanidinium cations, and metals. Our analysis confirms that these compounds are enantiomers exhibiting 3D hierarchical supramolecular structures that are constituted by 2D sublayers and sustained by noncovalent bonding interactions.

elements.content: Two new chiral copper­(II) coordination polymers comprising octacopper­(II) subcomponents were synthesized through the investigation of the interplay between tartrate ligands, guanidinium cations, and metals. Our analysis confirms that these compounds are enantiomers exhibiting 3D hierarchical supramolecular structures that are constituted by 2D sublayers and sustained by noncovalent bonding interactions.
elements.clean_text: Two new chiral copper(II) coordination polymers comprising octacopper(II) subcomponents were synthesized through the investigation of the interplay between tartrate ligands, guanidinium cations, and metals. Our analysis confirms that these compounds are enantiomers exhibiting 3D hierarchical supramolecular structures that are constituted by 2D sublayers and sustained by noncovalent bonding interactions.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of chiral coordination polymers (CPs) have been the subject of extensive studies as a result of their aesthetical structures, higher connectivity and stability, and potential applications. Up to now, the majority of reported chiral CPs are built from mono- or dimetallic units with a variety of organic ligands judiciously selected, while chiral CPs are comprised of high-nuclearity (>2) units are still rare. The fabrication of high-nuclearity cluster-based CPs continues to provide a challenge because of the complexity of the building units’ size, nuclearity, and intercluster connection modes. Thus, our work is aimed at searching for new asymmetric units of high nuclearity to construct novel chiral CPs of copper­(II) and other metals.
elements.clean_text: The design and synthesis of chiral coordination polymers (CPs) have been the subject of extensive studies as a result of their aesthetical structures, higher connectivity and stability, and potential applications. Up to now, the majority of reported chiral CPs are built from mono- or dimetallic units with a variety of organic ligands judiciously selected, while chiral CPs are comprised of high-nuclearity (>2) units are still rare. The fabrication of high-nuclearity cluster-based CPs continues to provide a challenge because of the complexity of the building units' size, nuclearity, and intercluster connection modes. Thus, our work is aimed at searching for new asymmetric units of high nuclearity to construct novel chiral CPs of copper(II) and other metals.

elements.content: It is a well-established strategy to fabricate polynuclear cluster-based CPs with the aid of versatile polynucleating ligands. The chiral tartaric acid (tart), which contains both alkoxide and carboxylate groups, is a great candidate ligand. Further, the use of the easily accessible enantiopure l or d form of tartrates, which causes the structures to crystallize in enantiomeric crystal forms, makes it a more predictable approach to the synthesis of enantiomerically pure CPs. In order to guide the formation of hierarchical networks, structure-directing agents (SDAs) are often required during the synthesis. In this respect, the guanidinium cation, [C­(NH2)3]+, is an outstanding SDA by virtue of its great ability to form hydrogen bonds and retain its cationic character in a wide range of pH values and thus can act as a multiconnecting node in the formation of several networks. Therefore, it is intriguing to explore the interplay among the planar guanidinium cation, chiral tartrate ligands, and CuII ions in the assembly process of CPs. Herein, we present the synthesis, structure, and chiroptical and magnetic properties of two enantiomerically pure chiral copper­(II) CPs, namely { Na 5 [ C ( NH 2 ) 3 ] [ Cu 8 ( L ‐TartH − 2 ) 4 ( L ‐TartH − 1 ) 2 ] · 22 H 2 O } n ( L‐ 1 ) { Na 5 [ C ( NH 2 ) 3 ] [ Cu 8 ( D ‐TartH − 2 ) 4 ( D ‐TartH − 1 ) 2 ] · 22 H 2 O } n ( D‐ 1 )
elements.clean_text: It is a well-established strategy to fabricate polynuclear cluster-based CPs with the aid of versatile polynucleating ligands. The chiral tartaric acid (tart), which contains both alkoxide and carboxylate groups, is a great candidate ligand. Further, the use of the easily accessible enantiopure l or d form of tartrates, which causes the structures to crystallize in enantiomeric crystal forms, makes it a more predictable approach to the synthesis of enantiomerically pure CPs. In order to guide the formation of hierarchical networks, structure-directing agents (SDAs) are often required during the synthesis. In this respect, the guanidinium cation, [C(NH2)3]+, is an outstanding SDA by virtue of its great ability to form hydrogen bonds and retain its cationic character in a wide range of pH values and thus can act as a multiconnecting node in the formation of several networks. Therefore, it is intriguing to explore the interplay among the planar guanidinium cation, chiral tartrate ligands, and CuII ions in the assembly process of CPs. Herein, we present the synthesis, structure, and chiroptical and magnetic properties of two enantiomerically pure chiral copper(II) CPs, namely      {   Na   5    [ C   (   NH   2   )   3   ]   [   Cu   8     ( L   -TartH   - 2   )   4     ( L   -TartH   - 1   )   2   ]  ⋅ 22   H   2   O }   n    ( L- 1 )            {   Na   5    [ C   (   NH   2   )   3   ]   [   Cu   8     ( D   -TartH   - 2   )   4     ( D   -TartH   - 1   )   2   ]  ⋅ 22   H   2   O }    n    ( D- 1 )

elements.content: The l-1 and d-1 enantiomers were prepared in good yields by the reaction of l-(+)- or d-(−)-tart with Cu­(OAc)2 and [C­(NH2)3]2CO3 in a HOAc/NaOAc buffer solution at room temperature. It is important to bear in mind that, although the mixture of copper­(II) and tartrate known as Fehling’s solution has been widely recognized, only a few compounds with defined structures in tartratocuprate chemistry have been revealed. As elaborated by Klüfers, the formation and crystallization of the tartratocuprate complexes are extremely sensitive to reaction conditions, such as the pH, the excess of copper­(II) or tartrate, etc. Thus, a number of synthetic factors that play a determining role in the formation of these two framework compounds should be emphasized.
elements.clean_text: The l-1 and d-1 enantiomers were prepared in good yields by the reaction of l-(+)- or d-(-)-tart with Cu(OAc)2 and [C(NH2)3]2CO3 in a HOAc/NaOAc buffer solution at room temperature. It is important to bear in mind that, although the mixture of copper(II) and tartrate known as Fehling's solution has been widely recognized, only a few compounds with defined structures in tartratocuprate chemistry have been revealed. As elaborated by Klüfers, the formation and crystallization of the tartratocuprate complexes are extremely sensitive to reaction conditions, such as the pH, the excess of copper(II) or tartrate, etc. Thus, a number of synthetic factors that play a determining role in the formation of these two framework compounds should be emphasized.

elements.content: First, l-1 and d-1 were obtained only when [C­(NH2)3]2CO3 was introduced during the reaction. The synthesis of two compounds by replacing [C­(NH2)3]+ with other large cations (such as Gd3+ and Cs+) was unsuccessful, indicating the significance of [C­(NH2)3]+ as the SDA. Second, mixing Cu­(OAc)2, tart, and [C­(NH2)3]2CO3 in a ratio of 1:1:4 is decisive for the single-crystal growth of l-1 and d-1. It is interesting to note that l-1 and d-1 are tartrate- and guanidinium-deficient in terms of the mother liquid’s constitution. Third, we found that the choice of the HOAc/NaOAc buffer solution at pH 5.5 is crucial for the successful synthesis. When the reactions were performed in other buffers (such as Na2CO3/NaHCO3, NaH2PO4/Na2HPO4, and HCOOH/HCOONa), neither l-1 nor d-1 was formed. Intriguingly, the copper/tartrate stoichiometry of l-1 and d-1 is in line with the octameric complex, with indeterminate structures detected in previous studies. The stereoselective effects between metal ions and ligands from the solution studies may contribute to the design and synthesis of novel chiral CPs with crystal structures, and vice versa.
elements.clean_text: First, l-1 and d-1 were obtained only when [C(NH2)3]2CO3 was introduced during the reaction. The synthesis of two compounds by replacing [C(NH2)3]+ with other large cations (such as Gd3+ and Cs+) was unsuccessful, indicating the significance of [C(NH2)3]+ as the SDA. Second, mixing Cu(OAc)2, tart, and [C(NH2)3]2CO3 in a ratio of 1:1:4 is decisive for the single-crystal growth of l-1 and d-1. It is interesting to note that l-1 and d-1 are tartrate- and guanidinium-deficient in terms of the mother liquid's constitution. Third, we found that the choice of the HOAc/NaOAc buffer solution at pH 5.5 is crucial for the successful synthesis. When the reactions were performed in other buffers (such as Na2CO3/NaHCO3, NaH2PO4/Na2HPO4, and HCOOH/HCOONa), neither l-1 nor d-1 was formed. Intriguingly, the copper/tartrate stoichiometry of l-1 and d-1 is in line with the octameric complex, with indeterminate structures detected in previous studies. The stereoselective effects between metal ions and ligands from the solution studies may contribute to the design and synthesis of novel chiral CPs with crystal structures, and vice versa.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that two compounds are enantiomers ( and S4 in the Supporting Information, SI) exhibiting 3D hierarchical supramolecular structures that are constituted of 2D sublayers and sustained by charged-assisted +N–H···O– hydrogen bonds between the tartrate ligands in layers and [C­(NH2)3]+. As depicted in , 2D sublayers comprise windmill-like tetramers [Cu32(TartH–2)16(TartH–1)8]24– ({CuII 8}4 or {CuII 32}) as building blocks. In each tetramer, two forward-facing subcomponents [Cu8(TartH–2)4(TartH–1)2]6– ({Cu8}) are connected by two identical backward-facing {Cu8} via tartrates (Figure S1 in the SI). Further investigation of the crystal structures of these two compounds reveals that the Cu–O bond lengths are in the range of 1.86–2.84 Å for both l-1 and d-1 (Flack parameters: 0.06 and 0.07). In the {Cu8} subcomponents, there are two different coordination types of the eight CuII centers (). Four of the CuII centers are best described as distorted [4 + 1] coordinate, with the apical bond (2.27–2.77 Å) to either an O– anion of the tartrate ligands or an (outer) water ligand. The pentacoordination for CuII is not unusual in coordination chemistry. The other four are [4 + 2] typical coordination ( and S2 in the SI). Six tartrate ligands in {Cu8} adopt three kinds of coordination modes: two act as tridentate ligands linking two Cu centers, two others act as tetradentate ligands linking three Cu centers, and the last two act as pentadentate ligands connecting four Cu centers ( and S3 in the SI). On the basis of these coordination modes, four {Cu8} subcomponents are linked by four carboxyls of tartrate ligands, forming the windmill-like {CuII 32} tetramer. As shown in , adjacent {CuII 32} windmills are connected by sharing the {Cu8} unit, generating a 2D sublayer of {[Cu8(TartH–2)4(TartH–1)2]6–} n in which the {Cu8} unit serves as a four-connected node. Guanidinium cations are associated with the voids between two sublayers, each forming six hydrogen bonds (N···O, 2.79–3.12 Å) with four {Cu8} units and one water moiety, and thus act as 5-connecting nodes to construct the 3D framework ( and S4–S6 in the SI). This hydrogen-bonding motif of guanidinium cations in l-1 and d-1 is different from that in the reported high symmetrical networks, which are conferred by guanidinium’s unique 3-fold structural symmetry (Figure S7 in the SI). Presumably, the interplay between guanidinium cations with specific binding mode and the asymmetrical units plays a significant role in the formation of l-1 and d-1.
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that two compounds are enantiomers ( and S4 in the Supporting Information, SI) exhibiting 3D hierarchical supramolecular structures that are constituted of 2D sublayers and sustained by charged-assisted +N-H⋅⋅⋅O- hydrogen bonds between the tartrate ligands in layers and [C(NH2)3]+. As depicted in , 2D sublayers comprise windmill-like tetramers [Cu32(TartH-2)16(TartH-1)8]24- ({CuII 8}4 or {CuII 32}) as building blocks. In each tetramer, two forward-facing subcomponents [Cu8(TartH-2)4(TartH-1)2]6- ({Cu8}) are connected by two identical backward-facing {Cu8} via tartrates (Figure S1 in the SI). Further investigation of the crystal structures of these two compounds reveals that the Cu-O bond lengths are in the range of 1.86-2.84 Å for both l-1 and d-1 (Flack parameters: 0.06 and 0.07). In the {Cu8} subcomponents, there are two different coordination types of the eight CuII centers (). Four of the CuII centers are best described as distorted [4 + 1] coordinate, with the apical bond (2.27-2.77 Å) to either an O- anion of the tartrate ligands or an (outer) water ligand. The pentacoordination for CuII is not unusual in coordination chemistry. The other four are [4 + 2] typical coordination ( and S2 in the SI). Six tartrate ligands in {Cu8} adopt three kinds of coordination modes: two act as tridentate ligands linking two Cu centers, two others act as tetradentate ligands linking three Cu centers, and the last two act as pentadentate ligands connecting four Cu centers ( and S3 in the SI). On the basis of these coordination modes, four {Cu8} subcomponents are linked by four carboxyls of tartrate ligands, forming the windmill-like {CuII 32} tetramer. As shown in , adjacent {CuII 32} windmills are connected by sharing the {Cu8} unit, generating a 2D sublayer of {[Cu8(TartH-2)4(TartH-1)2]6-} n  in which the {Cu8} unit serves as a four-connected node. Guanidinium cations are associated with the voids between two sublayers, each forming six hydrogen bonds (N⋅⋅⋅O, 2.79-3.12 Å) with four {Cu8} units and one water moiety, and thus act as 5-connecting nodes to construct the 3D framework ( and S4-S6 in the SI). This hydrogen-bonding motif of guanidinium cations in l-1 and d-1 is different from that in the reported high symmetrical networks, which are conferred by guanidinium's unique 3-fold structural symmetry (Figure S7 in the SI). Presumably, the interplay between guanidinium cations with specific binding mode and the asymmetrical units plays a significant role in the formation of l-1 and d-1.

elements.content: Schematic of ball-and-stick diagrams showing stepwise the assembly of {[C­(NH2)3] n [Cu8(TartH–2)4(TartH–1)2] n }5n− in l-1 from the {CuII 32} tetramer building block (left) to the 2D sublayer (middle) and 3D hierarchical supramolecular structure (right). Color code: Cu, blue; N, orange; C, gray. H atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  Schematic of ball-and-stick diagrams showing stepwise the assembly of {[C(NH2)3] n [Cu8(TartH-2)4(TartH-1)2] n }5n- in l-1 from the {CuII 32} tetramer building block (left) to the 2D sublayer (middle) and 3D hierarchical supramolecular structure (right). Color code: Cu, blue; N, orange; C, gray. H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: To investigate the chiroptical activities of these two compounds, the circular dichroism (CD) spectra of both compounds in the solid state were measured (a). These studies revealed that the CD spectra of l-1 and d-1 are mirror images and confirmed that l-1 and d-1 are enantiomers. The spectra of l-1 and d-1 exhibit Cotton effects at 254, 300, and 630 nm, which are quite different from those of l-(+)- and d-(−)-tart, exhibiting only a single Cotton effect at 215 nm (Figure S15 in the SI). The observation of such induced CD further substantiates that the chirality of the materials derives from the 3D supramolecular frameworks rather than the free tart. In addition, the CD spectra of l-1 and d-1 in the solid state were compared with those in solution (Figure S16 in the SI), revealing an extra band at 630 nm in the solid state, which can be attributed to the well-structured supramolecular assemblies held by noncovalent bonding interactions in the solid state. This gave a hint on the 2D-layered structures of {Cu32} n in solution, which were further confirmed by scanning electron microscopy, atomic force microscopy, and small angle X-ray scattering analysis (Figure S17–22 in the SI).
elements.clean_text: To investigate the chiroptical activities of these two compounds, the circular dichroism (CD) spectra of both compounds in the solid state were measured (a). These studies revealed that the CD spectra of l-1 and d-1 are mirror images and confirmed that l-1 and d-1 are enantiomers. The spectra of l-1 and d-1 exhibit Cotton effects at 254, 300, and 630 nm, which are quite different from those of l-(+)- and d-(-)-tart, exhibiting only a single Cotton effect at 215 nm (Figure S15 in the SI). The observation of such induced CD further substantiates that the chirality of the materials derives from the 3D supramolecular frameworks rather than the free tart. In addition, the CD spectra of l-1 and d-1 in the solid state were compared with those in solution (Figure S16 in the SI), revealing an extra band at 630 nm in the solid state, which can be attributed to the well-structured supramolecular assemblies held by noncovalent bonding interactions in the solid state. This gave a hint on the 2D-layered structures of {Cu32} n  in solution, which were further confirmed by scanning electron microscopy, atomic force microscopy, and small angle X-ray scattering  analysis (Figure S17-22 in the SI).

elements.content: (a) CD spectra of l-1 and d-1 in the solid state. (b) χM T (○) versus T plots for l-1, with the field dependence of magnetization for l-1 (inset). The red line represents the best fit using the spin Hamiltonian.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) CD spectra of l-1 and d-1 in the solid state. (b) χM T (○) versus T plots for l-1, with the field dependence of magnetization for l-1 (inset). The red line represents the best fit using the spin Hamiltonian.

elements.content: For magnetic characterization, the direct-current susceptibility data of both l-1 and d-1 were measured in a temperature range of 2–300 K with an applied magnetic field of 1000 Oe. Plots of the temperature dependence of χM T versus T for l-1 and d-1 are similar and are shown in b (Figure S24 in the SI). For l-1, the room temperature χM T value of 1.99 cm3 K mol–1 is lower than the calculated value of 3.00 cm3 K mol–1 for eight isolated spin-only CuII ions (S = 1/2 and g = 2). Upon cooling, the χM T value decreases rapidly from room temperature to 0.14 cm3 K mol–1 at 30 K and then drops gradually to 0.02 cm3 K mol–1 at 2.0 K, which is in agreement with an S = 0 ground state for l-1. The above data were fitted to the spin Hamiltonian in using the program PHI, which gives g = 2.07, J 1 = −65.8 cm–1, J 2 = −120.9 cm–1, and J 3 = 1.2 cm–1. Three exchange pathways can be seen clearly in the asymmetric unit (Figure S25 in the SI). Magnetization curves for l-1 at temperatures below 2 K (b, inset) reveal that the magnetization increases rapidly and reaches a saturation of 0.025 Nβ at 80000 Oe. The field dependence of magnetization at low temperatures further strongly confirms the presence of antiferromagnetic interaction. H = − 2 J 1 ( S 1 S 3 + S 3 S 6 + S 6 S 1 + S 2 S 5 + S 5 S 8 + S 8 S 2 − 2 J 2 ( S 6 S 4 + S 6 S 7 + S 8 S 4 + S 8 S 7 ) − 2 J 3 ( S 7 S 4 )

elements.content: In summary, two copper­(II) CPs with 3D hierarchical chiral supramolecular structures constructed from {Cu8}4 building units have been obtained by the facile synthesis in aqueous solution with good yields. The CD spectra of l-1 and d-1 reveal a significant induced optical activity of the antiferromagnetic {CuII 32} n frameworks. Crystal structure analysis implies that the guanidinium cations play a significant role in guiding the formation of the larger copper­(II) frameworks as SDAs. The successful synthesis of the chiral copper­(II) CPs based on our investigation of the interplay between multidentate polynucleating ligands, [C­(NH2)3]+ cations, and metal ions not only provides new examples of enantiomerically pure chiral materials but also opens up new avenues for the design and synthesis of underexplored chiral homo- and heterometallic CPs comprised of high-nuclearity units.
elements.clean_text: In summary, two copper(II) CPs with 3D hierarchical chiral supramolecular structures constructed from {Cu8}4 building units have been obtained by the facile synthesis in aqueous solution with good yields. The CD spectra of l-1 and d-1 reveal a significant induced optical activity of the antiferromagnetic {CuII 32} n  frameworks. Crystal structure analysis implies that the guanidinium cations play a significant role in guiding the formation of the larger copper(II) frameworks as SDAs. The successful synthesis of the chiral copper(II) CPs based on our investigation of the interplay between multidentate polynucleating ligands, [C(NH2)3]+ cations, and metal ions not only provides new examples of enantiomerically pure chiral materials but also opens up new avenues for the design and synthesis of underexplored chiral homo- and heterometallic CPs comprised of high-nuclearity units.

metadata.title:
Enantiomerically Pure Chiral {CuII
32}‑Based
2D-Layered Frameworks: From the Asymmetric
Octacopper(II) Subcomponents to 3D Hierarchical Supramolecular Structures
